Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust') is committed to managing claims fairly, sensitively and economically. The vast majority of patients receive exemplary care, but occasionally things go wrong. The Trust recognises that when things go wrong, those who suffer harm as a result are entitled to be appropriately compensated.

This policy aims to ensure that all claims are managed efficiently and effectively. The policy must be adhered to by all staff working for the Trust, and those whom may be required to assist in the investigation of a claim.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Set out the claims management process as required by the NHS Resolution Reporting Guidelines 2017 ‘the 2017 Guidelines' (refer to appendix 2) under the following schemes:
Clinical Negligence Scheme for Trusts (CNST);
Liabilities to Third Parties (LTPS);
Property Expenses Scheme (PES) and;
Employees' and Public Liability Scheme (ELS).
Provide information and guidance to all staff who are involved in a claim.
Definitions

table_items.text: An allegation of negligence and/or a demand for compensation, usually following an adverse event or incident, resulting in personal injury or loss.
A hearing held in a court to determine the circumstances of a person's death.
NHS Resolution is responsible for handling clinical and non- clinical claims made against NHS bodies in England
These include complaints/incidents/inquests that present a significant litigation risk. These claims will usually require investigation and reporting to NHSR
Serious Incident- Defined by NHS England as: “Serious Incidents include acts or omissions in care that result in;

unexpected or avoidable death, unexpected or avoidable injury resulting in serious harm - including those where the injury required treatment to prevent death or serious harm, abuse, Never Events, incidents that prevent (or threaten to prevent) an organisation's ability to continue to deliver an acceptable quality of healthcare services and incidents that cause widespread public concern resulting in a loss of confidence in healthcare services”.
The amount of money paid to the claimant in respect of a claim.
The patient's medical notes, including all paper and electronic files.
The person bringing the claim. This may be the patient, or someone acting on their behalf.
Letter of Claim- details the allegations of the claim
Letter of Notification- sent by the claimant to confirm that they are considering bringing a claim against the Trust.
Letter of Response- the Trust's formal response to the claim

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Duties of Committees within the trust
4.1.1 Trust  Board  will  seek  assurance  that  the  claims  management  process  is working effectively.
4.1.2 Quality Governance Committee will receive and scrutinise pertinent claims data by exception, and report to the Trust Board in accordance with their terms of reference.
4.1.3 MSE Risk and Compliance Group will review and scrutinise quarterly claim data, and escalate any exceptions to the Quality Committee in accordance with their Terms of Reference.

4.1.4 Executive Review Group will review any incidents giving rise to a claim where that  incident  has  not  previously  been  investigated  and  confirm  whether  a retrospective investigation is required.
4.1.5 Mortality Review Group will review and disseminate any learning identified from closed claims.
Duties of individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 Chief Executive is responsible for the overall handling of claims within the Trust.

4.2.2 Chief Medical Officer responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes and training are available to ensure that clinical staff are able to comply with the contents of this document.
4.2.3 Medical Directors have an on-going day-to-day responsibility for delivering the organisation's strategic objectives which includes the elements contained in this policy.

4.2.4 Group Director- Governance, Risk & Compliance has strategic oversight and management of the claims process. Acts as a key point of escalation for complex and/or high profile cases, and determines which cases should be presented to the Trust Board as necessary.

4.2.5 Head of Legal Services  will provide a specialist source of clinical legal expertise to staff and service users of the Trust (s); to take responsibility for the appropriate handling of clinical legal work and coronial matters for the MSE sites.

4.2.6 Senior Managers  must liaise with the legal services team to provide information and statements for inquests and claims. They must ensure that learning from claims is identified and disseminated to all relevant staff in their Directorate.

4.2.7 Legal Services Manager has day to day line management of the legal services team, overall responsibility for the proper management of claims; and a duty to escalate appropriate cases to the Head of Legal Services.
4.2.8 Legal Services Officers are responsible for the routine management of claims including the reporting of claims and requesting information on behalf of NHSR/ Trust solicitors.
4.2.9 Legal Services Assistants support the administrative needs of the entire legal services team and facilitate the smooth running of claims process.
4.2.10 All staff have a responsibility to be aware of this policy and;
Types of claims
Definition of a Claim and the NHSR Schemes Relevant to the Trust
5.1.1 A claim is defined by National Health Service Resolution (NHSR) as:

5.1.2 “Allegations of clinical negligence and/or a demand for compensation made following an adverse clinical incident resulting in personal injury, or any clinical incident which carries significant litigation risk for the Trust”.

5.1.3 NHSR is a Special Health Authority that has been responsible for handling clinical negligence claims made against National Health Service (NHS) bodies since 1995 and liabilities to third party and property expenses claims since 1999.
5.1.4 The  Liabilities  to Third  Parties  Scheme  (LTPS)  and  the  Property  Expense Scheme (PES) are collectively known as the Risk Pooling Scheme for Trusts (RPST).
5.1.5 The Trust is a member of both Clinical Negligence Scheme for Trusts (CNST) and RPST.
Clinical Negligence (CNST) Claims

5.2.1  CNST covers all clinical negligence claims made against member trusts. The scheme indemnifies members for clinical negligence claims for incidents occurring on or after 1 April 1995. The extent of cover afforded to Trusts under CNST is outlined in the CNST Scheme Rules and NHS Indemnity available on the NHSR website (ref 1).
Non Clinical (RPST) Claims

5.3.1  RPST scheme covers all non-clinical claims including visitor and staff injury and normally relate to health and safety incidents. The extent of cover afforded to Trusts is outlined in the RPST rules which are available on the NHSR website (ref 1).
Private Patient Claims

5.4.1 Employees undertaking private practice at the Trust are acting as self- employed practitioners and as such are wholly responsible for the medical care given to private patients. The Trust is not legally responsible for dealing with claims concerning the medical practitioner and treatment given by them in a private capacity. The exception to this is where care is provided in the NHS setting by staff who were working in their NHS capacity. For example, an NHS nurse caring for a patient who has received treatment from a surgeon practicing
privately- in this scenario the Trust would be vicariously liable for any negligent nursing care.

5.4.2 Equipment used by such medical practitioners is the property of the Trust and therefore any claim brought about due to faulty equipment, the use and or misuse of equipment is the responsibility of the Trust and therefore will be handled under NHSR's claims procedure.
The claims process
Who can bring a claim?

6.1.1 Any person, who believes the Trust owed them a duty of care, may bring a claim where they can prove the Trust failed in this duty, and suffered loss or injury as a result. This may as a ‘litigant in person', with the person bringing their own claim; however, more usually the claim will be made through a solicitor or other legal representative.

6.1.2 Where the potential claimant is a child, or is deemed not to have capacity to bring a legal claim in accordance with the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (ref 2), a claim may be brought on their behalf by a ‘litigation friend'. A litigation friend must act in the best interests of the claimant and there must not be any conflict of interest that would prevent them so acting. The suitability of the litigation friend will be confirmed by the court. In the case of a child the litigation friend will usually be one of the child's parents.

6.1.3 In the event that a potential claimant dies, compensation may be claimed on behalf of the claimant's estate by the executor, administrator or personal representative of the estate. Dependents of a deceased claimant may also claim, following a death under the Fatal Accidents Act 1976 (ref 3).
Triggers for invoking the claims procedure
6.2.1 The Trust may be alerted of a claim, or potential claim, in a number of ways. The following list is not exhaustive:
6.2.2 An overview of the claims process is attached at Appendix
Disclosure of Health Records for Legal Advisors

6.3.1 Disclosure of health records is managed by the access to records team. When a new request is received, a copy of the letter is also sent to the legal services team for information. This is only relevant where the letter states that a claim is, or may be, pursued against the Trust. This is then logged as a potential claim and saved on the legal services team's secure drive.

6.3.2 On receipt of a new request, the access to health records team will review the letter and carry out their due diligence to ensure that all the appropriate authorities are in place to disclose the information.

6.3.3 If the letter also includes a request for information or documents not contained within the health records, for example copies of policies, minutes of meetings etc. these will be sourced and disclosed by the legal services team. A copy of all documents disclosed will be retained by the team for future reference.
When to inform the Legal Services Team

6.4.1 If any legal correspondence is sent to a ward/clinic/secretary directly, it should be discussed with the site based legal services team immediately, or as soon as practicably possible- See contact details in section 6.5 below. This is to ensure that the Trust is able to meet its reporting obligations.
6.4.2 The legal services team should also be contacted in the following circumstances:
How to contact the Legal Services Team
6.5.1  Each hospital site has a site specific legal team who are best contacted by email as follows:
Letter of Claim (LOC)

6.6.1 The Pre-Action Protocol for Personal Injury Claims CPR Part 5 (ref 5) sets out the requirements of a LOC. The LOC should clearly set out a summary of the facts on which the claim is based, together with an indication of the nature of any injuries suffered, and the way in which these impact on the claimant's day to day functioning and prognosis. Any financial loss incurred by the claimant should be outlined with an indication of the heads of damage to be claimed and the amount of that loss, unless this is impracticable.

6.6.2 On receipt of the LOC, the Trust will have 4 months to prepare a formal Letter of Response (LOR). The LOR will respond to each allegation and confirm whether the Trust intends to admit or deny them.
Letter of Notification (LON)

6.7.1 The claimant or their legal representative may wish to notify a defendant and/or the insurer as soon as they know a claim is likely to be made, but before they are able to send a detailed Letter of Claim. Particularly, for instance, when the defendant has no or limited knowledge of the incident giving rise to the claim, or where  the  claimant  is  incurring  significant  expenditure  as  a  result  of  the accident which he hopes the defendant might pay for, in whole or in part.

6.7.2 When a LON is sent, the letter will typically be titled ‘Letter of Notification' as opposed to ‘Letter of Claim'. The LON should be acknowledged by the Trust within 14 days; however, a formal LOR is not required. In some cases, a claim will not progress past a LON. The 4 month response window only begins when a formal LOC is received. However, the Trust may have sufficient information within the LON to start compiling relevant information for the claim and ‘get ahead' with the investigation.
COVID-19 Clinical Negligence Protocol

6.8.1 The patient safety charity Action against Medical Accidents (AvMA), NHSR and the Society of Clinical Injury Lawyers (SCIL) have signed up to the ‘COVID-19 Clinical Negligence Protocol', with the aim of improving the management of claims during the ongoing coronavirus situation.
6.8.2 The protocol is wide-ranging, covering:
moratoriums upon limitation until 3 months after the protocol ends;
making use of email to serve and receive documents the default position;
encouraging much more innovation for example on-line examinations of clients for medical expert reports;
encouraging more co-operation in the progress of claims, and in particular interim payments of damages and costs to avoid unnecessary court hearings;
settlement meetings and mediations to take place remotely wherever possible;
consideration of whether costs budgeting needs to take place initially or can be requested to be adjourned in order to save court and other resources.

6.8.3 Of particular note, and in contrast to other claims protocols to cover the current situation, is that the agreement continues in place indefinitely, until one of the parties gives notice to end it. The provisions are also subject to review, and possible refinement, every 8 weeks to continue to respond to the challenges of the current situation.
Extension Requests

6.9.1 The Limitation Act 1980 (ref 6) affords a claimant three years from the date of the alleged negligent incident, or the date of their knowledge of alleged negligent incident, to bring a claim. In cases in which the claimant is a child, the child has until three years after their 18th birthday to bring a claim. Where patients lack capacity, the limitation period does not commence until they regain capacity.

6.9.2 The claimant may request an extension of time to bring a claim against the Trust. As per section  above, claimants may request an extension to limitation by virtue of the COVID-19 Protocol which grants an extension to limitation of 3 months from the date that the Protocol is suspended. The date of suspension has not yet been determined, but presumably it will be once the impact of the virus is considered to cease.

6.9.3 The legal services manager will decide if the extension should be granted with input from the head of legal services/ NHSR if necessary. NHSR should be consulted if any non-standard or unique wording is requested by the claimant's solicitors. All correspondence pertaining to the extension of limitation requests must be sent to NHSR when reporting the claim.
Reporting a claim
What must be reported to NHS Resolution (NHSR)

7.1.1 The 2017 Guidelines require all new ‘Letters of Claim' to be reported via the NHSR reporting portal within 24 hours of receipt. This will be completed by the legal services team using secure login details. All documentation is saved on a secure drive with restricted access.

7.1.2 In  addition  to  letters  of  claim,  the   Guidelines  also  set  out  specific circumstances when NHSR must be notified of potential claims, or Incidents which pose a significant litigation risk to the Trust. See Appendix
File management

7.2.1 Every  Claim  will  be  recorded  on  Datix  or  the  Ulysses  Risk  Management System, and a unique ID number will be generated. The legal services officer will report the claim to NHSR and write to the claimant or their legal advisor to acknowledge receipt of the claim within 14 days.
7.2.2 On receipt of the claim, NHSR will appoint a case manager and advise the Trust accordingly. They will have a unique reference number, which must then be used in all correspondence with them.
7.2.3 NHSR will decide whether to instruct one of the panel solicitors who will take up the care and conduct of the claim on behalf of the Trust, or whether it will be managed by NHSR themselves.

7.2.4 For non-clinical claims of a low value (less than £25,000) the claimant's solicitor can  submit  the  claim  directly  to  NHSR.  When  this  happens  there  is  no requirement for the Trust's legal services team to report it to NHSR separately. However, the remainder of the above reporting process will still be followed in the usual way.
Investigation of the Claim
Triangulation of other investigations

8.1.1 At the outset of a new claim the legal services officer must check to see whether any previous investigation has been carried out, such as a complaint. A copy of all investigations, relevant policies and a copy of the health records should  be  obtained  and  sent  to  NHSR.  If  an  SI  investigation  has  been completed, the report will be sent in its entirety to NHSR for review. This may negate the need for individual staff reports in some cases.
Identifying key staff- Factual Witnesses
8.2.1  The claimant's health records will be reviewed by the legal services team and key staff will be identified. The legal services officer will email the relevant

Directorate to notify them of the claim, and the Directorate will liaise with the relevant staff to obtain their factual reports. Practical guidance for staff preparing a report for a claim is attached at Appendix
Reports from staff
8.3.1 The specific allegations set out in the Letter of Claim must be investigated; by interviewing and/or obtaining statements from the members of staff involved.

8.3.2 Where a report is required, the MSE legal services report template should be completed and returned to the legal services team (see Appendix 5). This will then be sent to NHSR/ panel solicitors for consideration

8.3.3 In the event that the claimant issues legal proceedings at court, more formal statements may be needed and these will be prepared by the solicitor acting for the Trust who will provide appropriate guidance- usually via a face to face meeting or telephone call.

8.3.4 Statements made by staff are potentially disclosable to the claimant during the course of the claim, unless the rules on legal privilege apply. This includes statements made during any Trust investigation, even before a LOC was received e.g. as part of an SI investigation.
Openness and honesty

8.4.1 All staff involved in the investigation of a claim must be mindful of the need to be open and honest throughout the legal process and in particular when preparing their reports. This is to ensure the timely resolution of the claim and to avoid prolonging the investigation to the detriment of all those involved.

8.4.2 Remedial action and apologies must be readily offered when appropriate in line with the statutory duty of candour and the Trust's ‘being open' principles. However, staff must not make any admission of negligence at any time without consulting with the legal services manager. Making inappropriate admissions could compromise the Trust's position in defending any claim and potentially its indemnity under NHSR rules.
8.4.3 NHSR has published guidance on the importance of ‘saying sorry', and how this can be distinguished from admitting fault. A copy of the guidance is attached (Appendix 6)
Expert evidence

8.5.1 In most cases, NHSR will require expert evidence to form a view on liability. Expert witnesses are always independent from the Trust, and the type of expert used will depend on the nature of the claim. In many cases several experts will be used if the claim touches on several speciality areas. For example in a birth injury claim, expert evidence may be needed from a midwife, obstetrician and neonatologist.
8.5.2 The expert(s) will review the claimant's health records together with all statements, investigations, relevant policies and any other relevant evidence.
They will then write a report setting out their view on whether there were any failings by the Trust.

8.5.3 The claimant will also obtain their own expert evidence, and at a later point in the claims process the claimant and defendant will exchange expert evidence so that each side can review each other's.
Responding to the Claim- Letter of Response (‘LOR')

Once all investigations are complete, panel solicitors or NHSR will prepare a report summarising their view on liability. This will include any opinion from the expert(s). A draft LOR is then drafted and sent to the Trust for consideration. The LOR must be sent to the claimant's legal advisor within 4 months from the date the LOC is received, however this can be extended by agreement between the parties.

If NHSR recommend that liability is accepted by the Trust, the legal services team will discuss this with the relevant staff involved and share the expert report(s) for learning purposes. Once the LOR is approved, a formal letter of apology is usually sent to the claimant.

If staff are not in agreement with the proposed admissions this will be discussed with NHSR and panel solicitors before proceeding. In some circumstances, amendments can be made to the proposed admissions, or if further evidence has come to light, it may then be possible to deny liability.
If liability is denied, the LOR will set out the reason for this and reference any supporting evidence/ guidance, including reference to an expert report (but not disclosing it at this stage).
Once the LOR is sent to the claimant, the claimant will review it and decide whether to continue with the claim.
Settling the claim
A claim can be settled at any stage of the formal legal process, however in most cases it will be after a LOR has been served, and expert evidence has been obtained.

If the Trust makes a full denial of the claim in the LOR, the claimant may decide not to continue with their claim, usually this is because their legal advisors do not believe their claim has good prospects, or would be unlikely to succeed at trial. If a claim has been issued at court, the claimant will serve a ‘Notice of Discontinuance' on the Trust, and usually the Trust can recover their costs of defending the claim. If proceedings have not been issued, the claimant may simply cease to correspond altogether and NHSR will close their file.

In some cases it will be necessary for the Trust to partially admit liability; this may be because investigations have shown some failings in the care provided. However, even if there has been fault, the claimant must prove that the failing caused some injury. It may be possible for the Trust to defend the claim on the basis that there was some fault, but the fault did not cause the harm- this is called a ‘causation defence'.

If the Trust concedes on liability and causation, then a settlement can usually be reached between the parties which will avoid the claim proceeding to trial. When this happens, a ‘Round Table Meeting' (RTM) will be arranged for the parties to agree an amount for damages. If an agreement is reached, this will be drafted into a settlement agreement and signed by the parties. If the case involves a child it will be referred to the court for approval. In cases involving children, the court will often grant an anonymity order which prevents the media from naming the child in any publications.
How much will a claim be worth?

10.5.1 This depends on the extent of the injury and the length of time that the injury will affect the claimant. ‘Damages' is the name given to the monetary value of the claim, or the amount paid to the claimant. The precise amount is calculated by legal guidelines and previous case law.

10.5.2 NHSR and our panel solicitors will value a claim and where appropriate, negotiate a settlement. In addition to Damages, costs will also be incurred by both parties, if the Trust admits liability; a payment towards the claimant's costs will usually be paid.
Delegation Limits

10.6.1  The Trust does not have delegated authority to settle claims covered by the NHSR schemes. If an admission of legal liability is made without the approval of the NHSR the Trust's scheme cover may be voided. Equally, NHSR should not make admissions without the Trust's authorisation. Occasionally NHSR will give delegated authority to solicitors acting on their and the Trust's behalf to settle claims up to a set limit. If this happens, the Trust is still required to authorise any admissions of liability.
Who pays for the Damages and Costs?

10.7.1  All CNST and RPST claims brought against the Trust are covered by the NHSR indemnity contract. The Trust pays an annual premium to NHSR which covers all damages and costs, with the exception of the excesses payable on some RPST claims.
Support for staff
Being involved in a claim can be distressing, particularly if the Incident giving rise to the claim resulted in death or serious injury, or involved a child. It is
important that staff are able to access appropriate support throughout the claims process.

The legal services team will provide guidance and support throughout the claims process. Staff should contact the team using the details in section 6.5 if they have any questions or concerns at any stage.

Line managers will be included in emails regarding the claim, and they will often be the best source of support for staff. Staff may also wish to nominate a colleague for support, and the legal services team will be happy to accommodate this.

All staff involved in an Incident which is the subject of a claim should have the opportunity to provide information and statements about the Incident, and have feedback on the outcome of the investigation.
Detailed guidance on what to expect when attending court is attached (Appendices 7-9).

Emotional support for staff is also available from the MSE Health & Wellbeing Team. Full details of the support on offer can be found on the staff intranet pages; alternatively they can be contacted as follows:
Tel: 01268 524900 (ext. 3591) 08:00 – 16:00 Monday- Friday Email: occhealth@btuh.nhs.uk
Learning from claims

The Trust is committed to learning from claims. In the vast majority of cases, the incident giving rise to the claim will have already been investigated by the Trust either as part of a SI investigation, or as a complaint or inquest.

Where a new claim is reported that has not previously been reported as an incident, the legal services team will review the case as per the process detailed at Appendix  If indicated, the head of legal services will refer the case to the Executive Review Group (‘ERG') for consideration. The ERG will assess whether any retrospective investigation is required. This may include declaring the Incident as an SI.

The Trust will identify learning through these contemporaneous or retrospective investigations, however in addition to this the legal services team will ensure that any additional learning highlighted by NHSR is identified and shared with the Directorates.

Learning identified from closed claims is shared via the monthly MSE Oversight Group and quarterly to the MSE Risk and Compliance Group. Key themes identified in claims are triangulated with the other governance divisions to ensure that areas of concern are identified and acted on.
Where the claim arises from a death, learning is shared via the MSE Mortality Review Group on a quarterly basis which forms part of the group's central learning log for learning from deaths.
Approval and implementation

This policy was reviewed and approved by all members of the legal services team and presented to the Southend Risk and Compliance Committee. The approved policy was sent to members of the MSE Risk and Compliance Committee and approved by email. The final version was then sent to the document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the legal services team of the approved policy once it is uploaded to the Trust's intranets.
Training requirements
All staff within the legal services team will be trained on the claims process and receive regular updates on legal requirements via the Trust's panel solicitors.
Whilst specific training is not required for clinical staff, informational webinars and materials are available via the staff intranet, or by contacting the legal services team.

What are you proposing to change?
To bring together three site-specific claims management policies and amalgamate them into one up to date MSE policy.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To harmonise the claims management process for all MSE sites and ensure that staff have correct contact details for the teams.
Who benefits from this change and how?
All staff can expect the same process and support on all sites.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No, this policy enhances the previous guidance for staff involved in the claims process and provides up to date information about the support available post- merger.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Consultation will be with the local MSE legal services teams to ensure the document reflects current practice (refer to pages 1 & 2)
